title: U.S. Futures, European Stocks Mostly Down
description: U.S. Futures, European Stocks Mostly Down
content:
U.S. futures for the S&P 500 were down 0.1% and futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%. Changes in futures do not necessarily predict movements after the opening bell.

In Europe, the Stoxx Europe 600 declined 0.1% in morning trading. Ackermans & Van Haaren added 2.8% and Rheinmetall rose 2.7%. On the other hand, NatWest Group sunk 3.8%, and Lloyds Banking Group dropped 2.8%. The FTSE 100 lost 0.1%. Other stocks in Europe were mixed as France's CAC 40 decreased 0.1% and Germany's DAX held steady.

In commodities, Brent crude dropped 0.7% to $67.52 a barrel, and WTI crude dropped 0.8% to $64.11 a barrel. The European benchmark price for natural gas, the Dutch futures contract TTF, was flat at 31.71 euros a megawatt hour. The German 10-year Bund yield rose by 1 basis point to 2.71% from 2.698%, and the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury climbed by 1 basis point to 4.222% from 4.209%. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions. Stocks in Asia were mixed as Japan's Nikkei 225 index fell 0.3%, whereas Hong Kong's Hang Seng gained 0.9%. China's benchmark Shanghai Composite gained 0.4%. -This article was automatically generated by MarketWatch.
summary: U.S. futures for the S&P 500 were down 0.1% and Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%. European stocks were also mixed, with the Stoxx Europe 600 declining by 0.01%. The German 10-year Bund yield rose by 1 basis point to 2.71%, while the 10-yr Treasury rose by a point to 4.09.
shortSummary: US, European, and Canadian stock markets mostly declined, with key markets like New York seeing mixed fortunes, while oil prices rose and global economic stability remained uncertain.
argos_summary: U.S. equity futures were flat, with the S&P 500 down 0.1% and the Dow 0.2%. European stocks were largely unchanged, with the Stoxx 600 down 0.1% and the FTSE 100 flat, while individual names like Ackermans & Van Haaren (+2.8%) and Rheinmetall (+2.7%) outperformed and banks such as NatWest and Lloyds fell 3.8% and 2.8% respectively. Commodities saw a modest decline, with Brent at $67.52 a barrel and WTI at $64.11, while natural gas futures were unchanged. Bond yields edged higher, with the German 10‑year Bund at 2.71% and the U.S. 10‑year Treasury at 4.222%. Asian markets were mixed, with the Nikkei down 0.3%, Hang Seng up 0.9% and Shanghai Composite up 0.4%.
